text: okay it's mark Wiens here in Bangkok
Thailand today I am going to make a
recipe for thumb cocci which is one of
the most famous Thai soups a coconut
milk-based soup and it is delicious
so for this thumb cocci recipe you're
going to need about six cups of coconut
milk 400 grams of chicken I used two
chicken breasts three stalks of fresh
lemongrass about a thumb-sized chunk of
galangal about six to ten kaffir lime
leaves five to ten tied chilies a couple
of limes you can use any kind of
mushroom but I'm using oyster mushrooms
two small Tomatoes one big white onion
or two small ones a bunch of cilantro
and finally some salt I am in Thailand
so I'm going to be using fresh coconut
milk because it's easy to get here but
if you cannot get fresh coconut milk and
if you need to use the can of coconut
milk you can still do that but sometimes
coconut milk in a can is a little more
thick and buttery than when it's fresh
so if you use a can of coconut milk you
need to sort of tone it down with some
water so maybe one can of coconut milk
too one can of water the first step is
to take your galangal and cut off a good
thumb sized chunk of the root part of it
it can be kind of tough but just try to
slice it into strips you might have to
hammer your knife with your palm cutting
the galangal is just going to release
the flavor better when it's cooking next
grab the lemongrass slice off the very
bottom care off the outer leaf and then
slice it diagonally again this method
will help release the flavors when it's
cooked let your stove on a medium heat
and then first start heating three cups
of the coconut milk so only use half of
it first then you can immediately toss
in the lemongrass and galangal now
leaving your coconut milk heating start
to chop up your chicken I used two
chicken breasts for this recipe and I
cut them into medium sized chunks now
just before the coconut milk comes to a
boil then you can go ahead and toss in
all your chicken give it a quick stir
and then add another three cups of
coconut milk now you want to turn down
your heat to a medium low take a handful
of Thai red chillies I used about five
for this recipe pull off the stems and
then slice them diagonally you can then
go ahead and add the chopped chillies
directly into the soup give it a gentle
quick stir and then add about 200 grams
of oyster mushrooms your coconut milk
should still not be boiling yet but it
should be pretty hot and it might almost
be a little foamy this is alright stir
it for about one minute
and move over to slice up the white
onions
after peeling them cut them in half
first and then into big wedges
he immediately tossed them into your
soup now the big trick about cooking
coconut milk is to stir it gently and to
only stir in one direction this will
help so the coconut milk doesn't start
to curdle but remains a nice smooth
texture coconut milk is a delicate
ingredient so treat it very gently when
you're cooking it next take your
tomatoes cut off the stem slice them in
half and cut them into wedges
keep stirring your soup and when you can
see it's on the verge of boiling go
ahead and toss in the tomatoes then take
your kaffir lime leaves and just tear
them with your hands before throwing
them into soup cook for another few
minutes stirring occasionally until you
can tell the chicken and mushrooms are
fully cooked you don't really want your
soup to come to a full boil so just stir
it as it's slow cooks and you can turn
down the heat if it starts to boil too
much then add about half a teaspoon of
salt to start with and then you can
always add more salt if you need it
since the coconut milk is so delicate
you want to make sure it doesn't
actually like come boiling over to too
much it can come to a slight boil but
you don't want it to really boil boil up
for long so you want to just keep an eye
on it just keep stirring it really
gently and then just wait basically
until your ingredients are are all the
way cooked through as soon as you think
the chicken and the mushrooms are done
you want to just turn off the heat
because you don't wanna overcook it once
the heat is off you can go ahead and
take a handful of fresh cilantro chopped
off the roots slice it medium fine and
add it to the soup give it a gentle stir
then slice a couple of limes and juice
them into a bowl adding the lime juice
and cilantro at the very end when the
heat is already off is going to ensure
that they have the fullest taste and
that they don't make the soup bitter I
used about four tablespoons of lime
juice but you can start by adding less
and do a few taste tests until it's
perfect for your taste buds should be
slightly sour to complement the rich
coconut milk it needs a little more lime
juice
the final step is to dish your hot thumb
cut guy into a bowl and start eating
okay that thumb got guy is ready and in
Thailand it's normally eaten like a
curry so you eat it with rice as opposed
to eating it like a soup straight that
onto the rice beautiful you just kind of
grab a bite with some rice okay
hmmm that is marvelous rich and creamy
from that coconut milk has a nice look
bit of a sour tinge from that lime juice
a good amount of heat from those chilies
and just an awesomely flavorful Thai
soup right there you can drink some of
the juice also creamy and a little bit
sour mmm such a good so wonderful indeed
okay thank you so much for watching this
Thai Street food recipe be sure to stay
tuned for more recipes and lots more
food videos
you
